awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Leveraging the Collective Strengths of e4usa and FiRST for Greater Impact on the Future Engineering Workforce (e4usa+FIRST)
awd_abstract_narration:
Industry demands for highly trained science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) professionals are growing at a rate not supported by current post-secondary student enrollments. Efforts have been made primarily in isolation at the pre-college level to educate and excite students about possible careers in STEM. The e4usa+FIRST project is an unprecedented effort that establishes a partnership between two existing programs - Engineering for US All (e4usa) and For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology (FIRST) - in an effort to leverage collective strengths toward furthering the democratization of engineering education. This collaborative effort prepares teachers to educate, inform, and excite youth about careers in engineering for greater overall impact on the future engineering workforce.

The project’s overarching goal is to design and test a myriad of blended e4usa and FIRST models to be implemented within underserved communities that have been unable to offer or maintain engineering experiences at their schools. Targeting unserved communities is designed to intentionally expand the reach and impact of these two programs. The overarching goal is accompanied by four objectives: 1) establish blended e4usa+FIRST models for high schools in underserved communities, 2) prepare teachers and schools to implement an e4usa+FIRST model, 3) link teachers with mentors, universities, and industry, and 4) explore program scalability and sustainability through innovative business models and technological tools. The overall effort entails a kick-off workshop, multiple development sprints, summer professional development, academic year community of practice, mentorship, university and industry partnerships, and scalability and sustainability initiatives. Implementation will be evaluated using teacher interviews, student focus groups, classroom observations, and surveys. Additional efforts exploring mechanisms to support scalability, sustainability, and incorporation of new schools into the engineering education ecosystem are intended to increase the longevity and overall impact of the e4usa+FIRST program. This effort provides the foundation for testing the likelihood of the collaboration’s future success, specifically within underserved communities. The blended approach has the potential to contribute greatly to recruitment and retention of a more diverse future engineering workforce, while demonstrating the value of such efforts to university and industry partners. The result will be a better educated citizenship with a growing interest in engineering and engineering careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
The project has achieved several key outcomes, demonstrating significant progress in integrating engineering education with extracurricular activities, supporting teachers, developing innovative resources, and conducting impactful research. These outcomes highlight the effectiveness of the project and its potential for long-term sustainability and broader adoption.

1. Creation and Refinement of Blended Models:

  • In Year 1, the project team created four distinct models for blending e4usa and FIRST programs: 1) curricular + extracurricular, 2) co-curricular + extracurricular, 3) sequential curricular, and 4) concurrent curricular. These models were designed to integrate engineering education with various extracurricular activities, providing flexible options for implementation in different educational settings.
  • Throughout Year 2, these models were refined based on feedback and practical application by participating teachers. This iterative process ensured that the models were effective and adaptable to diverse classroom environments.
  • Participating teachers have been actively implementing and continuously testing these models, contributing to the ongoing improvement and validation of the blended approaches. This hands-on experience has provided valuable insights into best practices and potential challenges, leading to more robust and effective educational strategies.

2. Recruitment of Participating Teachers:

  • A total of 19 teachers participated in the e4usa+FIRST initiative across the pilot phase, with nine teachers engaged in Year 1, ten teachers involved in both Year 2 and Year 3, and four teachers participating in all three years. This sustained engagement demonstrates the program's appeal and effectiveness.
  • While some teachers left the program due to various reasons such as school switches, retirements, and changes in school support, the majority remained committed. Notably, 12 of the 13 teachers participating in the 2023-2024 cohort have expressed interest in continuing with future grant efforts, indicating strong support and satisfaction with the program.

3. Participant Support:

  • The project established an effective professional learning program for teachers, including a summer professional development (PD) session, a yearlong community of practice, winter PD, yearlong coaching, university and/or industry liaison interactions, a Slack discussion board, and virtual robotics help desk/office hours. This multi-faceted support system ensured that teachers received continuous and comprehensive assistance throughout the year.
  • Based on teacher feedback, the support mechanisms evolved to better meet the needs of participants. This responsiveness to feedback has enhanced the effectiveness of the professional learning program and ensured that teachers felt supported and empowered in their roles.

4. Development of the XRP:

  • The creation of the XRP (eXtended Reality Platform) provided students with an open-source classroom resource that is both affordable and accessible. The XRP kit successfully addressed cost barriers, making advanced technology available to a wider range of students.
  • The XRP has been adopted by partners worldwide, demonstrating its value and impact. The project's unique approach to open hardware and software has inspired new programs, such as the precision agriculture robot developed in collaboration with Future Farmers of America and the University of Idaho. This spinoff from the research efforts highlights the broader applicability and influence of the XRP.

5. Impactful Research and Insights:

  • Research conducted as part of the project has provided valuable insights into the needs and impacts on teachers—an essential stakeholder group in the engineering education ecosystem. Feedback from teachers and students regarding their experiences with various e4usa+FIRST offerings has been overwhelmingly positive.
  • The project team has shared the impact and best practices through multiple presentations and publications, contributing to the broader academic and professional discourse on engineering education and inclusive mentoring. These dissemination efforts ensure that the project's findings benefit a wider audience and influence future initiatives in the field.

 


Last Modified: 08/04/2024
Modified by: Steve Efe

por.por_txt_cntn:
The project has achieved several key outcomes, demonstrating significant progress in integrating engineering education with extracurricular activities, supporting teachers, developing innovative resources, and conducting impactful research. These outcomes highlight the effectiveness of the project and its potential for long-term sustainability and broader adoption.


1. Creation and Refinement of Blended Models:

In Year 1, the project team created four distinct models for blending e4usa and FIRST programs: 1) curricular + extracurricular, 2) co-curricular + extracurricular, 3) sequential curricular, and 4) concurrent curricular. These models were designed to integrate engineering education with various extracurricular activities, providing flexible options for implementation in different educational settings.
Throughout Year 2, these models were refined based on feedback and practical application by participating teachers. This iterative process ensured that the models were effective and adaptable to diverse classroom environments.
 Participating teachers have been actively implementing and continuously testing these models, contributing to the ongoing improvement and validation of the blended approaches. This hands-on experience has provided valuable insights into best practices and potential challenges, leading to more robust and effective educational strategies.



2. Recruitment of Participating Teachers:

A total of 19 teachers participated in the e4usa+FIRST initiative across the pilot phase, with nine teachers engaged in Year 1, ten teachers involved in both Year 2 and Year 3, and four teachers participating in all three years. This sustained engagement demonstrates the program's appeal and effectiveness.
While some teachers left the program due to various reasons such as school switches, retirements, and changes in school support, the majority remained committed. Notably, 12 of the 13 teachers participating in the 2023-2024 cohort have expressed interest in continuing with future grant efforts, indicating strong support and satisfaction with the program.



3. Participant Support:

The project established an effective professional learning program for teachers, including a summer professional development (PD) session, a yearlong community of practice, winter PD, yearlong coaching, university and/or industry liaison interactions, a Slack discussion board, and virtual robotics help desk/office hours. This multi-faceted support system ensured that teachers received continuous and comprehensive assistance throughout the year.
Based on teacher feedback, the support mechanisms evolved to better meet the needs of participants. This responsiveness to feedback has enhanced the effectiveness of the professional learning program and ensured that teachers felt supported and empowered in their roles.



4. Development of the XRP:

The creation of the XRP (eXtended Reality Platform) provided students with an open-source classroom resource that is both affordable and accessible. The XRP kit successfully addressed cost barriers, making advanced technology available to a wider range of students.
The XRP has been adopted by partners worldwide, demonstrating its value and impact. The project's unique approach to open hardware and software has inspired new programs, such as the precision agriculture robot developed in collaboration with Future Farmers of America and the University of Idaho. This spinoff from the research efforts highlights the broader applicability and influence of the XRP.



5. Impactful Research and Insights:

Research conducted as part of the project has provided valuable insights into the needs and impacts on teachersan essential stakeholder group in the engineering education ecosystem. Feedback from teachers and students regarding their experiences with various e4usa+FIRST offerings has been overwhelmingly positive.
The project team has shared the impact and best practices through multiple presentations and publications, contributing to the broader academic and professional discourse on engineering education and inclusive mentoring. These dissemination efforts ensure that the project's findings benefit a wider audience and influence future initiatives in the field.
